author: adayofjoy
body: It's not specifically tech stocks that are inflated faster, but growth stocks. Low PE ratio tech stocks such as Intel, Cisco and IBM are still sitting at depressed levels.

author: Admirable_Nothing
body:
Maybe some historical perspective can help.  Let's take AMZN, MSFT and CSCO.

In early 2000, MSFT was 53 and a darling of the internet.   It again hit 53 in early 09 passing through $6/sh in the meantime.  So 9 years for breakeven.

In early 2000, AMZN was $64 and a darling of the internet.   It again hit $64 in Dec of 2015 after passing through $16 in the intervening years.   So 15.7 years for breakeven.

In early 2000, CSCO hit $77/sh and was and is the real backbone of the internet.   It has passed through $10/sh in the intervening years and is now $39.81/share.  Maybe in another 10-20 years it will recover its $77/share price.  So a 30 or 40 year recovery period?

Nobody knows what the future holds.   We do know that valuations are crazy and will take phenomenal growth to justify just the current stock prices.   I think your analysis that tech is the future is spot on.  But will that provide enough growth to justify the current prices over the next 10-20 years?   I am not so certain.

author: Admirable_Nothing

Yes. Use Yahoo Finance and highlight the stock you want and go to "chart" and enter a custom time period.   Any dividends are marked by a large D on the time line and a split is a large S.

BTW, every Cisco employee I heard that their FA recommended they sell some after option exercise to diversify for safety said "No, it is going to $100."   The comments clients would give in late 99 and early 00 were the exact same words the youngsters today are saying re:  Today's Tech.

author: couldbeworse2
body:
BMO equity strategist Brian Belski noted that foreign interest in Canadian equities has all-but disappeared,

"Lack of foreign and even domestic interest in Canadian equities has hit extreme levels, depressing both valuations and relative price performance. However, we believe when (not if) interest returns, Canadian equities are likely to see a strong tailwind, particularly within Financials… "

Mr. Belski also highlighted the recent underperformance of dividend investing strategies but believes these sectors are poised for a comeback,

“Dividend Underperformance Has Been Extreme … With the thirst for yield poised to return, we believe higher yielding sectors with reasonable payout ratios are poised to benefit. This is particularly true for both Communication Services and Financials, which have relatively high yields and among the lowest payouts within the high yield sectors.”

BMO provided a top picks list of North American dividend growth stocks. The list is too long to list all the names, but prominent stocks include BCE Inc., Telus Corp., McDonald’s Corp., PepsiCo Inc., Enbridge Inc., Manulife Financial Corp., Power Corp of Canada , JP Morgan Chase & Co., Royal Bank, Amgen, Gilead Sciences Inc., Merck & Co. Inc., Canadian National Railway Co., Lockheed Martin Corp., Microsoft Corp., Cisco Systems Inc. and Brookfield Infrastructure Partners LP.

author: marilius12
body:
The price of a stock alone says nothing about it being cheap or expensive. You need to also consider the number of shares outstanding. That's why instead of looking at the stock quote you should look at ratios like P/E.

So, what you're asking is what are some value stocks with relatively low P/Es compared to the S&P average for example. There are several sectors that are "cheap" - these are your banks like JPM and BAC, manufacturers like MMM and HON, even some tech like INTC, CSCO, and STX.

Note that low P/E are often indicative of low growth expectations. So you are trading stability (low beta) and dividends for capital appreciation.

author: notbrokemexican
body:
The difference is that Cloudflare is an organization with an extremely cheap and distributed solution that is eating the market share of AWS, GoDaddy, and Cisco. You get a shit ton out of the box for extremely cheap.

Fastly is a professional tool where networking professionals at places like Reddit or TikTok will use for late-stage development. Both can exist together in a large organization; the CDN market is not a zero sum game and the economy is too large for one player.

Reddit and Tiktok compete with Facebook so they need every inch of competition they can get. That is what Fastly provides which isn't necessarily everyones equal concern.



I will go with cloudflare on the simple premise that online assets and digitally communicated assets will only increase in value greatly and so will the layers of security that wrap it.

Cloudflare's primary competition is Akamai.
Fastlys primary competition is limelight networks

author: FinndBors
body:
This is terrible advice. In 2000, you could argue the same for CSCO, SUNW, MSFT, ORCL.

These companies aren’t going anywhere, but only one out of the four ever reached their 2000 highs (and it took sixteen years). The rest are still down from highs.

Broad index for the bulk of your investments. Buy individual stocks with some only if you have a high confidence bet that it will outperform.

Edit: Just want to add that if you go with a broad index, last I checked S&P was over 40% tech related companies, so you are still pretty heavy weight tech.

author: BuyLowSellNever
body:
Security is a very saturated market and there are many different players, forget about the “Cloud” part and just focus on who offers the *best* security products, as every product utilises cloud in some form or another it doesn’t make sense to look for “Cloud Security Vendors” as that’s not really a thing.

Security really falls into two main categories; securing the endpoints (encryption, device control etc) and securing the gateway (encryption, device control etc.) so figuring out who does that best is a good place to start.

Companies like Microsoft and Cisco (both mentioned here) are **not** security companies, they *offer* an element of security but their broader product offering is not security, so that’s not where their focus is.

Good luck in your search!

author: GoldenPresidio
body:
I really don't have an answer for you on that because these companies don't sit around and wait. If Snowflake sat around and didn't improve the product at all them maybe two years with all the user testing the cloud guys do? They really do not want to break their existing product at all because they stress resiliency. Either way that's not how it would go down.

Look at Twilio for example. They have SO many competitors that all do the same shit on the surface: cloud based communications. But Vonage/Nexmo, Plivo, Avaya, Cisco, etc have not been able to catch up Twilio because Twilio keeps on expanding and innovating. Now Twilio has the biggest breadth of services from any of them and is straight up way easier to use.

Maybe Snowflake keeps making their UI better. Maybe they integrate with more data sources before everybody else. Maybe they keep providing better analysis than the other guys. The innovation can keep them ahead even if the cloud guys make their product better.

I think analyzing the catchup for a company like Fastly is more direct in that AWS CloudFront would just need to get even closer to the edge locations to decrease latency under Fastly's 35 millisecond one and be more competitive. You can see them doing this with the new Wavelength product.

edit: one last thing I want to note is that there is plenty of room for both of them to grow! The cloud market is still not close to fully being penetrated so even if the cloud guys create a good product, it doesn't mean doom and gloom for all these other companies

author: ice_cream_winter
body:
Awesome read thanks. The parallels are there, it's hard to imagine the right side of the graph but it's always good to be aware of the bear case. Cisco has done well over the past 10 years but their stock price only made it up to 70% of the dot com high. 

If we imagine that Tesla follows the same kind of story it is possible that they do incredibly well over the next 10 years but the price of the stock might still be lower than it is today by the end of the next market cycle. Do the people spamming 'if you believe in the stock then why does it matter' actually consider the price of the stock could stagnate for quite some time? I think Tesla will do well but I'm not buying at these prices. It's price action is sentiment driven so when sentiment changes price will travel very fast in opposite direction. The best time to buy is when people are on here complaining about Tesla and Elon, not when they believe that Tesla will power everything from their toothbrushes to their hyperloops to work within the next 6 months.

author: hedgefundaspirations
body:
That is total bullshit. Microsoft had $20b in revenue in 2000. It hit $60 a share during the bubble. Now no one would say that it wasn't eventually going to be worth that, but it sure as shit wasn't at the time. It crashed and it took 16 years to recover to $60 a share. Seems like a perfectly plausible scenario for Tesla as well.

And Cisco is an even better example. It had $19 billion in revenue in 2000 and manufactured hardware. It hit $80 a share before crashing to $14. Even today 20 years later it has only recovered to half it's fever pitch peak currently trading at $40.

One more for good measure, to kind of demonstrate the three possible paths for Tesla. WorldCom in year end 1999 did $37 billion in revenue, and we all know what happened to WorldCom.

You've got your history dead wrong.

author: Shoopshopship
body:
Tesla is in a speculative bubble. When something is running on hype and everyone thinks it has a bright future, people buy into it initially seeing it as a long term inbestment but as the price goes up and the investors becoming cockier people follow them and chase the trend seeing the gains those investors got. The problem, is that you are buying a piece of a business and for a business to justify being valued so high it needs to make a significant amount of money and when that doesn't happen at maximum expectations, the stock price collapses. 

Check out this article from 2002 when Cisco became the world's largest publicly traded company briefly: https://www.cnet.com/news/cisco-ascends-to-most-valuable-company/

Cisco is a valuable company and makes a lot of money, but people's expectations severely overpriced what people were paying for it. If you bought near the top and held all this time, you have not got your money back not factoring in dividends. 

The bears aren't saying Tesla doesn't have a bright future, what they are saying is the talk that "Tesla is not a car company" is speculation. Until Tesla actually makes money in this area it may never be worth 300 billion dollars, but thats what its trading for. When Apple released the iPhone in 2007, the market cap did not immediately shoot up to 1 trillion dollars. So you are basically taking a huge gamble on a stock that is making far less income than any other stock trading at that level to pull through on technology that may or may not be revolutionary at an unforseen time in the future. That is why it is crashing and why it will likely continue to crash. 

TL;DR Tesla is way ahead of itself on valuation and will likely continue to go down

author: TheM0L3
body:
As a brand it has definitely blown up.  People use “Zoom” as a synonym for video conference, and there is definitely value in being a leader in a market to that extent.  People say “I’m going to Zoom with them later” even if it is a video chat on another platform because of the name recognition.  You look at a company like Google who’s name became synonymous with searching and you can see where that kind of brand recognition can lead.

But that brand name will only get them so far if they don’t find some new revenue streams.  They are the biggest fish in the pond by a good margin but they don’t even have half the market and it is a crowded pond.  Not to mention they are swimming with some really big fish like Microsoft, Google, Facebook, and Cisco.

They have a lot of users but until they either control a very dominant market share or make more money on those users it is obvious that their valuation is way out of line.  Most of their users don’t pay anything and they have a payment model for 1000 users at $200 a month.  That’s 20 cents per month per user.  At that rate you could sign up all 7 billion people on the planet and still only be making 140 million a month.  Doesn’t exactly show a high profit ceiling for this company as-is and you can see why so many are baffled by their valuation.

author: NobodySpecific2
body:
Nothing but inertia. Zoom was easy to get setup fast when it looked like "we need to do something right now because we will be getting a stay at home order any moment" 

Larger companies that can afford this own SIP trunks and stuff will want to go back to self hosted solutions to save costs eventually when they have the IT resources available to make it happen.  The other player Microsoft, Cisco, are not going to just sit by and let Zoom be "the online meeting collaboration platform." o365 is all about being a package deal, and MS is going to want to make sure "Teams" is a part of that.  I don't have position because I don't know what the time frame will be but once "review or telecom solution" becomes a department priority again for IT in corporate America, I strongly suspect Zoom won't be the pick.

author: sumtastic
body: Believe it or not, the moat isn't small. Zoom's real key is how well they work with enterprise infrastructure. Once there, it's sticky as hell. They still have a lot of enterprise customers to land, so plenty of market left for them. Cisco and Microsoft have never addressed the asks of corporate UC and IT teams as well as Zoom does.

author: deadjawa
body:
Yeah but there’s a whole world of adjacent opportunities that you can dig into.  Focusing in on only TSLA is like focusing in on only CSCO or INTC in 2000 because they were the only big tech companies making money on the dotcom expansion.  TSLA is probably a good play, but there’s going to be lots of other winners that aren’t just vehicle manufacturers.  

I think the 10-100 baggers are in the application of EVs.  Tesla has maybe a 3x opportunity yet in front of them, 6x at most.  So why not look for the other companies that are killing it technologically that will benefit?

author: thri54
body:
>Why wouldn’t it be good long term?

It’s much cheaper to pay interest on a note then buyback stock at a later date, in most cases.  Especially if the capex returns significant value. 

If TSLA turned out to be a 2000 Cisco or Microsoft, issued shares at the top and started buybacks as they matured, and share prices dropped as the absurd expectations did, it would effectively be a negative interest loan.  

CSCO today is highly profitable, though they never lived up to the hype.  If they issued shares at $80 in 2000, and bought them back today at 40, that’s an excellent return for their current investors, not so much for the guys who bought at the peak two decades ago.

author: jokikinen
body:
In my opinion you also have to consider the market at large back when Cisco bubbled. Completely legless enterprises received incredible valuations—then it follows that the companies with actual promise should be worth more than those. The garbage companies were a catalyst that makes an additional component to the forces pushing the share price up. As of now we don’t have a similar context. The “bubbling” stocks are proven tech giants, not companies that were listed a month ago.

TSLA is definitely acting in a novel way and it should be noted. But we shouldn’t make the conclusion that it’s entirely similar with Cisco. There are major important differences which make the comparison hard.
